Header:
This is a whole-slide tissue section of an invasive colorectal adenocarcinoma stained with a 17-plex Immunooncology biomarker panel and imaged with the Orion system in a single
staining and scanning process. These data were collected in collaboration with the Harvard Laboratory of Systems Pharmacology. Images in this viewer show smaller sets of markers
that have been selected from the larger panel. 

The mucosal surface of the tumor is at the far right of the image. Tumor cells (Cytokeratin, E-Cadherin) invade beneath the mucosa into the smooth muscle layer seen in the center (SMA, smooth muscle actin).

Dense collections of immune cells can be seen expressing CD45 at the base of the mucosa (right) and at the invasive margin of the tumor in the muscle wall (center).

Waypoints.Name: Normal colonic epithelium
Waypoints.Description:
Uniform colonic glandular structures called crypts (cytokeratin, E-Cadherin) are  encircled by myofibroblasts in the lamina propria between the crypts that express smooth muscle actin (SMA). SMA also marks the muscularis mucosae – the boundary of the mucosa – seen at far left.

The lamina propria also contains capillaries and small lymphatic vessels (CD31).

There are scattered Ki67+ proliferating cells (nuclear) present in the crypts, which
are part of the normal regenerative process within the mucosa.

Waypoints.Name: Well-differentiated adenocarcinoma with immune collection
Waypoints.Description:
Adenocarcinoma cells express membrane cell-cell adhesion glycoprotein E-Cadherin uniformly in this area; cytoplasmic cytokeratins are prominent focally in groups of cells  that generally appear larger and have less uniform shape within the malignant glands.

In contrast to normal crypt cells, a large fraction of tumor cells are in proliferative  phase (Ki67).

A dense collection of activated immune cells (CD45RO) is prominent between the cancerous glands. A few of these cells are B cells (CD20).

Waypoints.Name: Interstitial collection of immune cells
Waypoints.Description:
The same interstitial collection of immune cells seen in the previous page is analyzed here with T cell markers that are included in the staining panel. 

Most of the cells in the
dense collection are CD4+ T helper cells which can also be seen between tumor cells
(cytokeratins).

Scattered within the CD4+ population are regulatory T cells (FOXP3, nuclear). There are CD8a+ cytotoxic T cells present but they are much fewer in number than CD4+ cells.

Waypoints.Name: Infiltrating border of carcinoma
Waypoints.Description:
Multiplexed imaging distinctly reveals the invasive border of the tumor. Small clusters of malignant “budding” cells seen in the center (cytokeratins) appear to have broken
off from the glandular structures and infiltrated further into the smooth muscle (SMA). Note that these cells are surrounded by T cells (CD3e) as part of the host response to these invasive cells.

The infiltrating border contrasts with other tumor regions in two ways. First, the proliferative fraction is much lower (Ki67, nuclear). Second, staining of E-Cadherin is reduced, and the presence of cytokeratins is more pronounced. This is consistent with a down-regulation of E-Cadherin in the invasive cells that is part of epithelial
to mesenchymal transition, leading to more aggressive tumor behavior.

Waypoints.Name: Immune checkpoints on individual cells and in neighborhoods
Waypoints.Description:
Macrophages are an important source of the checkpoint PD-L1 in tumors. PD-L1  binds PD-1 on T cells to suppress anti-tumor immune response.

Interstitial macrophages surrounding tumor cells (cytokeratins) in this region can be identified by the markers CD68 and CD163.

Co-localization of PD-L1 on macrophages expressing both markers can be seen prominently on the left.

On the right CD68+ macrophages are more prominent than CD163+, and the number  of PD-L1+ cells is lower, revealing a different “neighborhood” of expression. PD-1+ cells are present in both neighborhoods.

Waypoints.Name: Autofluorescence reveals a neurovascular bundle in the colon wall
Waypoints.Description:
Elastin and nerve fibers can be identified by autofluorescence detected and visualized by Orion as its own fluorescence channel.

The lower autofluorescent structure is an artery, just below a collapsed large caliber vein, both of which have prominent elastin fibers. Sparse nerve fiber remnants are seen next to the upper part of the vein.

Endothelial cells are identified by CD31. The neurovascular bundle is surrounded by cancer cells (cytokeratin, E-cadherin).
